critique: This document is an executive order from 1941 that prescribes regulations for within-grade salary advancements for government employees. It outlines the amounts of the increments, the conditions for receiving them, and the effective date. It also allows for additional advancements for meritorious service. It does not touch upon immigration, civil liberties, or social inclusion. It could be argued that it expands executive power, but it is also simply implementing existing laws and regulations. It centralizes control over federal employee salaries, so it leans towards federal primacy. It involves government in economic matters by setting salary guidelines.
